docs.text: Janne Pott Welcome to my homepage! I am a genetic epidemiologist working on genome-wide association studies and causal inference models (aka Mendelian Randomization). Research Objective The goal of my research is to contribute to personalized medicine via genetic epidemiology. This includes analyzing the molecular sex differences in multiple OMICS levels as well as the different risk profile for various diseases, which are also age-dependent. For this, I use genetic summary statistics from large-scale studies, genetic consortia and electronic health data in causal models of Mendelian Randomization. Current projects Multivariate MR (MVMR) using longitudinal exposure data Genetics and (MV)MR analyses of steroid hormones Genetics and (MV)MR analyses of PCSK9 levels MVMR of age at menarche and age at menopause on disease risk in women Contact Information Medical Research Council (MRC) - Biostatistics Unit (BSU) University of Cambridge Email / LinkedIn / GitHub / ORCID Last updated: 09/09/2025

docs.text: Genetics of steroid hormones and their impact on sex-biased outcomes still under construction About Biological sex is an independent risk factor for many diseases, their progression, and their respective biomarkers. Examples include coronary artery disease , chronic kidney disease , and Alzheimer's disease . Also immune response and inflammatory pathways differ between men and women. Within this project, I plan to analyse (hormonal) sex differences in multiple OMICS levels as well as complex diseases. Hormone levels highly depend on phase of life, with changes during puberty in both sexes, and menopause and the menstrual cycle in women. Hence, I will also include data from longitudinal studies and expand cross-sectional studies with data from electronic health records. Contact Do not hesitate to contact me in case you are interested in these kind of analyses, or if you have data to share! docs.title: Genetics of steroid hormones and their impact on sex-biased outcomes

docs.text: Biological sex is an independent risk factor for many diseases, their progression, and their respective biomarkers. Examples include coronary artery disease , chronic kidney disease , and Alzheimer's disease . Also immune response and inflammatory pathways differ between men and women. Within this project, I plan to analyse (hormonal) sex differences in multiple OMICS levels as well as complex diseases. Hormone levels highly depend on phase of life, with changes during puberty in both sexes, and menopause and the menstrual cycle in women. Hence, I will also include data from longitudinal studies and expand cross-sectional studies with data from electronic health records.
